Description: Get a firm grasp on Einstein's theory of relativity and how this ties into time dilation by watching this video.
Title: Einstein's Relativity: Time Dilation

Description: The song video at this link is about momentum and collisions. Fun way to review your understanding of momentum and collisions.
Title: MOMENTUM - The Physics Song

Description: This video demonstrates conservation of energy in a Newton's cradle. Why doesn't ball 5 reach 100% of the distance traveled by ball 1? The MythBusters want to see if a wrecking ball-sized Newton's cradle will work. What do you think might happen?
Title: Newton's Cradle

Description: Be amazed by how different frequencies of sound can split the grains into different patterns. (You may want to turn down the volume before watching this video.)
Title: Sound Waves

Description: This video ties the concepts of electromagnetic waves (microwaves) and standing waves. Did you know you can figure out the wavelength and energy of the microwaves by melting cheese?
Title: How a Microwave Oven Works

Description: This video demonstrates how a superconductor can float over a magnetic rail. Covers some advanced topics: superconductivity, quantum levitation, quantum locking.

Title: Boaz Almog "Levitates" a Superconductor

Description: A great video that shows how induction cooktops are made, courtesy of Discovery / Science Channel
Title: How It's Made Induction Cooktops

Description: This video demonstrates how to build a wind generator (the propellers, the casing, and of course all the electronics that comes with it).
Title: Wind Generators - How it's Made

Description: This video shows the process of manufacturing mirrors.
Title: Mirrors - How it's Made

Description: A quiz with fairly basic questions about distance and displacement where it is necessary to understand the difference between the two.
This fun article describes the motion of Batman and how, in real life, his cape would be near-useless in slowing him down when he jumps off a tall structure.
This website shows how Newton's Laws are applied to cute puppies in the circus ring. There is a short 2 minute video and some great diagrams and descriptions.
Use what you know about Newton's laws and gravity to play this game.
column18: Newton's First Law, Newton's Second Law, Newton's Third Law

Description: Simulation of Newton's cradle. Pay attention to how the energy is transferred through the cradle, instead of being lost.
This short simulation allows you to explore the different types of collisions and view them in terms of kinetic energy, velocity, and momentum.
A large number of simulations involving springs, collisions, and conservation of energy
This simulation allows you to explore how the pendulum length, pendulum mass, friction, and gravity affects the motion of the pendulum.
Play around with the frequencies, amplitudes, and conditions to vary the sound produced.
Simulation involving a lens, a light/source, and a projection. (This is for convex lens only.)
This simulation lets you see the effect when you change the mass, volume, and density (by changing material) of the block and the density of the fluid.
